definitions: move forward on hands and knees or by dragging the body along the ground
be full of or swarming with unpleasant things that seem to be moving
examples: The baby crawled across the floor towards her mother
We had to crawl through the narrow tunnel carefully
The old basement was crawling with spiders and insects
The crowded market seemed to crawl with pickpockets yesterday

definitions: create a drawing or color something using wax crayons as the medium
examples: The children crayoned colorful pictures during art class today
She carefully crayoned the outline before adding more details

definitions: drive someone insane or cause them to become extremely obsessed with something
produce a network of fine cracks on a surface such as pottery or paint
examples: The endless noise was enough to craze anyone living nearby
Social media has crazed teenagers with its addictive features
The extreme heat crazed the surface of the antique vase
Years of weathering had crazed the paint on the door

definitions: mix or beat ingredients together until they form a smooth creamy consistency
defeat someone completely and decisively in a competition or contest
examples: Cream the butter and sugar together for five minutes
She carefully creamed the ingredients until they were perfectly smooth
Our team creamed the opposition in yesterday's championship game
The champion boxer creamed his challenger in the third round

definitions: make a line or ridge in something by folding or pressing it
develop wrinkles or fold marks especially in fabric or paper
examples: She carefully creased the paper along the dotted line
Don't crease the documents when you put them away
His shirt creased badly during the long flight yesterday
The fabric tends to crease easily without proper care

definitions: bring something into existence through imagination, design, or physical construction
cause a particular situation or feeling to occur or come about
examples: The artist created a masterpiece from recycled materials yesterday
Scientists are working to create new sustainable energy sources
His reckless behavior created problems for the entire team
The new policy will create opportunities for small businesses

definitions: ascribe an achievement or quality to a particular person or thing
add an amount of money to an account or financial record
examples: Critics credit her with revolutionizing modern dance techniques completely
You should credit the original author in your research
The bank credited my account with the refund yesterday
They credited fifty dollars to each customer's loyalty card

definitions: move slowly and carefully in order to avoid being heard or noticed
gradually increase or advance beyond the usual or desirable limits
examples: The cat crept silently towards the unsuspecting bird outside
He crept downstairs trying not to wake the children
Inflation continues to creep upward despite government efforts yesterday
Doubt began to creep into her mind about the decision

definitions: gradually increase in loudness, intensity, or force to reach a climax
examples: The music crescendoed to a powerful finale that moved everyone
The protests crescendoed throughout the week before the election

definitions: reach the top of something such as a hill, wave, or metaphorical peak
examples: The hikers finally crested the mountain after hours of climbing
The wave crested and crashed dramatically onto the shore below

definitions: work as a member of a crew on a ship, aircraft, or film production
examples: She crewed on racing yachts during her summer vacations
He has crewed for several famous directors over the years

definitions: copy another person's work dishonestly and present it as your own
put a baby or young child in a crib for sleeping or containment
examples: Several students were caught cribbing answers during the examination
He cribbed most of his essay from online sources unfortunately
She cribbed the baby for his afternoon nap upstairs
The toddler refused to be cribbed during the daytime hours

definitions: cause or develop a painful stiffness in the neck or back muscles
examples: I cricked my neck sleeping in an awkward position yesterday
Don't crick your back lifting those heavy boxes improperly

definitions: make an activity illegal by passing laws against it or treating it as criminal
examples: The government plans to criminalize cyberbullying with new legislation
Many countries have criminalized the possession of certain drugs completely

definitions: compress something into small folds or ridges especially in hair or fabric
have a restricting or inhibiting effect on something's growth or development
examples: She crimped her hair for the eighties-themed party yesterday
The chef crimped the edges of the pie crust beautifully
Rising costs are crimping consumer spending across the country significantly
New regulations could crimp the company's expansion plans this year

definitions: become deep red in color especially from embarrassment, anger, or exertion
examples: Her face crimsoned when she realized everyone was watching
He crimsoned with rage at the insulting remarks yesterday

definitions: bend one's head and body in fear or in a servile manner
experience an inward feeling of embarrassment or disgust at something
examples: The dog cringed when its owner raised his hand
She cringed away from the aggressive stranger approaching her
I still cringe when I remember that awkward speech
Everyone cringed at his terrible attempt at humor yesterday

definitions: cause someone to become unable to walk or move properly through injury
severely damage or harm something's ability to function effectively or normally
examples: The accident crippled him for life tragically and unexpectedly
Polio crippled thousands of children before the vaccine was developed
The cyber attack crippled the company's computer systems completely
High taxes are crippling small businesses throughout the region

definitions: make or become firm, dry, and brittle through cooking or exposure
examples: Crisp the bacon in the oven for fifteen minutes
The autumn air crisped the fallen leaves perfectly yesterday

definitions: indicate the faults of someone or something in a disapproving way
examples: The media constantly criticises the government's handling of healthcare
Don't criticise her efforts when she's trying her best

definitions: indicate the faults of someone or something in a disapproving way
examples: Parents shouldn't criticize their children in front of others
The report criticized the company's safety procedures quite severely

definitions: evaluate something in a detailed and analytical way, especially academic or artistic work
examples: The professor critiqued each student's research proposal thoroughly yesterday
Art students learn to critique paintings using established methodological frameworks

definitions: create fabric or garments by interlocking loops of yarn with a hooked needle
examples: My grandmother crocheted beautiful blankets for all her grandchildren
She crochets scarves to sell at the local craft market

definitions: bend something, especially a finger or arm, into a curved or angled shape
examples: She crooked her finger to beckon him over silently
He crooked his arm for her to take while walking

definitions: hum or sing in a soft, low voice, especially in a sentimental manner
examples: The mother crooned a lullaby to her sleeping baby
The jazz singer crooned romantic ballads throughout the evening performance

definitions: cut something, especially hair or a photograph, to make it shorter or smaller
appear, occur, or come to someone's attention unexpectedly or suddenly
examples: She cropped her hair into a stylish pixie cut
The photographer cropped the image to focus on the subject
Problems keep cropping up with the new software system
His name cropped up during our conversation about candidates

definitions: adopt a position where the knees are bent and the upper body is brought forward and down
examples: The photographer crouched to get a better angle yesterday
She crouched behind the wall to avoid being seen

definitions: make the characteristic loud cry of a rooster, especially at dawn
express great pride or triumph about something in a boastful way
examples: The rooster crowed at sunrise every morning without fail
Several roosters crowed throughout the night keeping everyone awake
He constantly crows about his son's achievements to everyone
The winning team crowed about their victory for weeks

definitions: come together in large numbers or gather closely around someone or something
fill a space almost completely, leaving little room for movement
examples: Fans crowded around the celebrity hoping for an autograph
People crowded into the small shop during the sale
Tourists crowd the beaches every summer making them unbearable
Too many thoughts crowded her mind during the examination

definitions: ceremonially place a crown on the head of someone to invest them as monarch
form the top or highest part of something in a prominent way
examples: They will crown the new king in Westminster Abbey tomorrow
The queen was crowned in a magnificent ceremony decades ago
Snow crowned the mountain peaks throughout the winter months
A golden dome crowns the historic cathedral beautifully

definitions: sail about in an area without a precise destination, especially for pleasure
drive or travel around at a steady, comfortable speed without rushing
examples: They cruised the Mediterranean for two weeks last summer
The yacht cruised along the coastline enjoying perfect weather
Teenagers cruise the main street on Friday nights regularly
We cruised through the countryside enjoying the scenic views

definitions: break or fall apart into very small fragments or pieces like breadcrumbs
examples: The stale cookies crumbed when I tried to eat them
Be careful not to crumb the bread all over the table

definitions: break or fall apart into small fragments, especially over time
gradually disintegrate, deteriorate, or fall into ruin physically or metaphorically
examples: The old cookies crumbled in my hand immediately
She crumbled the cheese over the salad before serving
The ancient walls are crumbling from centuries of weathering
Their relationship crumbled under the pressure of financial stress

definitions: crush hard or brittle foodstuffs with the teeth making a loud grinding sound
process large amounts of data or numbers through intensive calculation
examples: The children crunched their cereal loudly at breakfast yesterday
She crunched through the apple during the quiet meeting
The computer crunched the numbers all night to complete analysis
Analysts are crunching data to predict market trends accurately

definitions: lead or take part in an energetic and organized campaign for social or political change
examples: She crusaded for women's rights throughout her entire career
Environmental groups crusade against deforestation in the Amazon rainforest

definitions: press or squeeze forcefully so as to break, damage, or distort in shape
defeat utterly or suppress completely through overwhelming force or pressure
develop a brief but intense infatuation with someone romantically
examples: Don't crush the cardboard boxes before recycling them properly
The machine crushes grapes to make wine every autumn
The army crushed the rebellion within days of its beginning
The new evidence crushed his hopes of winning the case
She's been crushing on her classmate since September started
He crushes easily but never acts on his feelings

definitions: form or cause to form a hard outer layer or covering on something
examples: The mud crusted on his boots after the hike
Snow crusted over during the cold night making walking difficult

definitions: shed tears as an expression of distress, pain, or sorrow
shout or scream loudly to attract attention or express strong emotion
examples: The baby cried all night keeping everyone awake unfortunately
She cried with joy when she heard the good news
He cried for help when he fell into the river
The vendors cried their wares in the busy marketplace

definitions: form or cause to form crystals through a chemical or physical process
make something become clear and definite in one's mind or in reality
examples: The sugar solution crystallized as it cooled down slowly
Salt crystallizes when seawater evaporates in the sun
Her thoughts finally crystallized into a coherent plan yesterday
The proposal crystallized after months of discussion and debate

definitions: cut food or other material into small cubic pieces of roughly equal size
examples: Cube the potatoes before adding them to the stew
The recipe says to cube the chicken into bite-sized pieces

definitions: give someone a signal to begin speaking, performing, or doing something
examples: The director cued the actors to enter from stage left
She cued the music at exactly the right moment yesterday

definitions: strike someone with an open hand, especially on the head or ear
examples: The angry parent cuffed the child for misbehaving badly
He playfully cuffed his friend on the shoulder yesterday

definitions: reduce the population of animals by selective slaughter or gather information from various sources
examples: Farmers cull weak animals from their herds every spring
She culled the best quotes from dozens of interviews yesterday

definitions: reach a climax or point of highest development after a gradual progression
examples: Years of research culminated in a groundbreaking scientific discovery
The festival culminates with a spectacular fireworks display every year

definitions: prepare and use land for growing crops or plants through agricultural methods
try to acquire or develop a quality, sentiment, or skill through deliberate effort
examples: Farmers cultivate their fields every spring before planting season
They cultivate organic vegetables in their greenhouse year-round
She deliberately cultivates relationships with influential people in business
You need to cultivate patience when teaching young children

definitions: maintain tissue cells, bacteria, or other microorganisms in conditions suitable for growth
examples: Scientists culture bacteria in petri dishes for medical research
The lab cultures stem cells for regenerative medicine studies

definitions: form one's hands into the curved shape of a cup to hold something
examples: She cupped her hands to drink water from the stream
He cupped his ear to hear the conversation better

definitions: check or restrain something undesirable from developing or increasing excessively
examples: The government is trying to curb inflation through monetary policy
Parents must curb their children's excessive screen time effectively

definitions: relieve a person or animal of symptoms of disease or condition
preserve meat, fish, tobacco, or animal skin by various methods including drying, salting, or smoking
examples: Antibiotics can cure many bacterial infections when used properly
The new treatment might cure certain types of cancer
They cure ham using traditional salt and smoking methods
The tobacco leaves cure in the barn for several weeks

definitions: form or cause to form a curved or spiral shape, especially hair
play the sport of curling by sliding stones on ice toward a target
examples: She curls her hair every morning before going to work
The smoke curled upward from the chimney into the sky
They curl competitively at the local ice rink every weekend
He learned to curl during his vacation in Scotland
